webTitle: Tesco hires farmers' voice to restore trust lost in horsemeat scandal

fields.standfirst: Senior executive at National Farmers' Union joins retailer as survey shows Britons are still sceptical about food safety
fields.body:
Tesco has poached a senior executive from the National Farmers' Union as it attempts to restore public trust following the horsemeat scandal. The move comes as a survey reveals that British consumers remain highly sceptical about the safety of food products.

Britain's largest retailer has appointed Tom Hind, corporate affairs director at the NFU, as director of agriculture in a new role designed to improve Tesco's relationship with farmers and suppliers.

The appointment follows a pledge by Tesco chief executive, Philip Clarke, at the NFU's annual conference this year to build stronger relationships with farmers and introduce a more transparent supply chain.

Tesco's UK sales have been hit by the horsemeat scandal, when horse DNA was found in four Tesco products including beef burgers. Other food retailers implicated in the furore included Lidl, Aldi and Iceland.

Hind helped create the voluntary code of practice for the dairy industry while at the NFU and has led NFU lobbying efforts on the new groceries code adjudicator, who is able to ifine supermarkets if they do not treat suppliers fairly.

In his new role, Hind will be the main point of contact between Tesco's commercial teams and farmers across the UK. Christine Tacon, the adjudicator, has said she is inclined to fine retailers a proportion of their turnover if they mistreat suppliers.

Kevin Grace, Tesco commercial director, said: "Tom is a respected figure in British agriculture and will bring with him a huge amount of hands-on farming experience. His relationship with farmers will ensure their views continue to be heard throughout Tesco."

Speaking at the NFU conference in March, Clarke indicated more business for British farmers, announcing a "sincere commitment to source more of our meat closer to home." He said: "Where it is reasonable to do so, we will source from British producers."

Tesco critics may not be satisfied with the appointment and will point to last year's controversial hiring of the former Food Standards Agency chief executive Tim Smith as group technical director.

Meanwhile, research by Mintel shows that consumer confidence in the UK food industry has been seriously dented by the horsemeat scandal. Six months since the crisis erupted, its survey found that just half of respondents trust the food industry to provide safe food to eat, with almost two fifths undecided.

Only 42% of consumers, taken from a nationally representative sample of 2,000 adults, believe the food industry can react to major food scares effectively, while less than a quarter believe that different elements of the supply chain work effectively together.

Consumer concerns about food safety centre on the complexity and lack of transparency around supply chains, reflecting a scandal that started in Ireland but soon raised concerns about the sourcing of meat across Europe.

Just 36% of consumers feel that food manufacturers are aware of where their ingredients come from, according to Mintel. The use of British-sourced ingredients was named as the top factor most likely to regain consumers' trust in supermarket products.

Alex Beckett, senior food analyst at Mintel, said: "That food should not be harmful should be one of the most basic of consumer expectations, yet only half of adults feel the UK food industry provides food that is safe to eat, signalling a widespread breakdown of trust in the agri-food chain, and suggesting the need for more active communications and greater transparency towards consumers."

Consumers who have purchased ready meals labelled as beef were also asked by Mintel about their attitudes following the scandal. Around one in five respondents were worried they might have bought affected products, while 18% said they will boycott beef ready meals as a result of the scandal. One out of ten say they will now avoid frozen ready meals.

webTitle: Banker contests £450,000 fine for allegedly disclosing inside information

fields.standfirst: Former JP Morgan executive denies involvement with Kurdish minister's $21m Heritage Oil share order
fields.body:
The Kurdish oil minister who allegedly received inside information from the former JP Morgan banker Ian Hannam later instructed brokers to buy up to $21m (£13.9m) of shares in Hannam's client Heritage Oil, a tribunal has heard.

Details of the order were disclosed in papers that form part of the Financial Conduct Authority's defence of its decision to fine Hannam £450,000 for disclosing inside information about Heritage in 2008. The banker, who stepped down from JP Morgan after the fine, began an appeal against the fine at a tribunal in London on Tuesday.

In explanation of the fine, the FCA, then part of the Financial Services Authority, said: "It is not suggested that any trades were conducted on the basis of the information disclosed by Mr Hannam."

The latest court papers, filed by the FCA, say: "The FSA did not consider that it had evidence that the purchase [on the instruction of Ashti Hawrami] was made on the basis of the information Mr Hannam provided to him."

Hawrami explained in a statement that the instruction to brokers at HSBC, on 16 October 2008, had been to purchase shares in a basket of oil companies in order to provide a hedge against investment in the troubled Norwegian exploration group DNO, which had interests in Kurdish northern Iraq.

"Nothing was going on with any of these companies that could have been considered as my having private knowledge as far as I was aware, and no rules were to be broken," he said.

Filings with the tribunal show that JP Morgan instigated its own internal investigation in parallel to FSA actions, which concluded that Hannam had "conducted business communications with third parties in a manner falling below the standards expected of you".

Internal disciplinary action required that he resign from the board of JP Morgan Chase; not initiate new business relationships; not act as nominated adviser to any listed company; and that he must have his mobile phone and emails monitored.

The case against Hannam focuses on two emails sent to Hawrami in September and October 2008, which regulators claim contain insider information in relation to the activities of Heritage in Uganda, which were being closely watched by the markets.

On 9  September, Hannam emailed the Kurdish regional government minister telling him that discussions were taking place between "Tony Buckingham's business" [a reference to the Heritage chief executive] and an unnamed potential bidder. It added that Hannam believed an offer would come in, and that offer would be priced at between £3.50 and £4 a share. Nine days later, the Takeover Panel requested that Heritage make a statement to shareholders, in which it confirmed a preliminary takeover approach.

The next day shares rose 18%. Hannam's second contentious email, sent on 8 October, contained a postscript: "PS. Tony has just found oil and it is looking good." This was at a time when news of drilling at Heritage's Warthog-1 well in Uganda was so sensitive that the group's staff had been barred from trading in company shares.

On 21 October 2008 Heritage announced to the stock market "a significant new discovery" at Warthog-1. That day, the FCA told the court, shares in the exploration group rose 14.6%.

Hannam's counsel, Laurence Rabinowitz QC, has urged the tribunal to throw out the fine order. "On a fair and proper analysis of the emails, neither contained inside information. Even if they did, this information was sent by or on behalf of Mr Hannam pursuant to his client's mandate and in the proper performance of his duties as a financial and strategic adviser."

Rabinowitz claimed that decision against Hannam had "sown confusion" as to where the boundary lay on inside information. It "demonstrates a possible failure on the part of the [FCA] properly to understand the nature of the work routinely (and honestly) carried out by financial advisers," he said. The investigation into Hannam had stemmed from a 2009 insider dealing inquiry into Mehmet Sepil, the chief executive of Genel Enerji, which led to a record fine of almost £1m. Genel was a Turkish company with which Heritage had at one stage been discussing a deal. The deal failed as, on the advice of Linklaters, Hannam and others took evidence to the UK authorities that appeared to show insider dealing in Heritage shares.

The tribunal hearing continues.

webTitle: Bank of England condemns lobbying by banks against new rules

fields.standfirst: Deputy governor of the Bank of England, Paul Tucker has called for  new measures to be introduced before the end of the year
fields.body:
City regulators have brushed aside complaints by Barclays and Nationwide over tough new liquidity rules, saying UK banks would need to put them into effect as soon as possible, years ahead of an international deadline of 2018.

The deputy governor of the Bank of England, Paul Tucker, responsible for financial stability, said lobbying against the change by the banks was "completely unacceptable", and regulators would not be deflected "one iota" from the task.

He told MPs the rules should be introduced before the end of the year to curb the risk exposure of Britain's highly leveraged banks.

Barclays and Nationwide complained vociferously against the "shock" decision by regulators last month to fast-track the new rules, which they said would harm their finances and ability to lend.

At a meeting last week Mervyn King, the former Bank of England governor, told MPs that large banks' executives had lobbied the Treasury and No 10 to block the rule changes before 2015.

Barclays hinted that it could restrict lending to households and businesses if the rules were to bite this year.

The row comes as US regulators on Tuesday made clear they intended to push ahead with the new rules on bank borrowing levels and higher reserves ahead of deadlines established by the Bank for International Settlements.

Much to the annoyance of the head of JP Morgan, Jamie Dimon, and of highly leveraged banks such as Wells Fargo, Dan Tarullo, the Federal Reserve governor in charge of regulation, promised a stricter lending ratio, tying the amount banks can lend to the equity held by shareholders.

He said the reserve was close to putting forward a plan that would place a tougher cap on leverage for US banks.

"The Basel III leverage ratio seems to have been set too low to be an effective counterpart to the combination of risk-weighted capital measures that have been agreed internationally," he said.

Banks have complained vociferously that regulators are demanding they move more quickly to safer levels of capital and lending.

The Tory MP Andrew Tyrie, who heads the Treasury select committee, said he was concerned that the banks were throwing their weight around.

Andrew Bailey, who heads the Prudential Regulation Authority, which will monitor banks and insurers, confirmed that George Osborne was approached by several banks over the new rules, but that the PRA's independence was confirmed by the chancellor.

"We are certainly aware that there are conversations that happened between the banks and officials and ministers," he said. "The thing that concerns me is that we are trying to build, frankly, a transparent process that has accountability in it."

Martin Taylor, a former Barclays chief and an external member of the financial policy committee, which will guard the financial system from a repeat of the 2008 crash, said: "The reason the banks are squawking is that the PRA and Andrew Bailey are doing their job, and you might say about time too."

Bailey said that banks were behind schedule in cleaning up their balance sheets after suffering extra costs from the payment protection insurance scandal and the euro crisis last year.

He said he wanted the rule in place as soon as possible and that regulatory staff were looking at banks' plans for how they could implement it.

"We have made clear that we will go through these with the public, with the institutions during the course of this month. And we will publish. We will make clear what the outcome of that is," Bailey told MPs.

The PRA said on 20 June that it would set a leverage ratio of 3% for UK banks, which would limit the amount they could lend relative to their capital.

Barclays has a leverage ratio of 2.5% after adjustments, while the Nationwide could only manage a 2% ratio.

Tyrie said: "FPC members today made clear that they feel a 3% leverage ratio is an appropriate minimum backstop and that the FPC can make recommendations in this area, even without an explicit power of direction. Bank lobbying of government only serves to reinforce the need for the power to set the leverage ratio to lie with the independent FPC, not the Treasury."

Lloyds is expected to split 600 branches into a separate business next year to increase competition in the banking sector following an attempt to sell the new business to the Co-op, which fell through.

The MP Jesse Norman asked Bailey why the Co-op's reported "lack of reserves" came as a surprise in December 2012 to Lloyds, when regulators were supposed to be aware of shortfalls.

Bailey said regulators discovered in 2011 that the Co-op was suffering from poor leadership and governance, coupled with a shortage of capital and liquidity. He said the Co-op was made aware of its concerns and he understood that Lloyds was informed.

The collapse of the deal proved an embarrassment to the Treasury, which had trumpeted it as part of wider reforms of the banking sector to make it more competitive.

Tyrie said there was a discrepancy between the testimony of Lloyds chiefs and the regulator.

"The chairman of Lloyds, Sir Win Bischoff, told the Treasury committee that Lloyds became aware of a potential capital shortfall at the Co-operative Group in December 2012. Andrew Bailey today said that he told the Co-op's board that it should inform Lloyds of the regulator's concerns, including over its capital levels, more than a year beforehand.

"[Bailey] also told us he has evidence to suggest his requests were complied with. The Treasury committee will want to look at whether the regulator's message got through, how it was conveyed and what, if any, action was taken."

webTitle: Carphone Warehouse managers to share multimillion-pound windfall

fields.standfirst: Up to 300 senior staff to receive average payouts of around £110,000 as reward for involvement in European-US venture
fields.body:
Carphone Warehouse managers are to share a £22m stock windfall after the unwinding of the retailer's alliance with America's Best Buy group.

Between 200 and 300 senior managers running Carphone stores in the UK and continental Europe will be given an estimated 9m free shares, resulting in average payouts of up to £110,000.

The scheme was set up in 2009 as a reward for staff involved in the joint venture between the mobile phone chain and Best Buy, which saw the US retailer take a 50% share in Carphone's UK and European operations. The bonus plan was due to run until 2015 but, according to the annual report published Tuesday, it will now pay out two years ahead of schedule.

It marks the end of an alliance conceived by the company's founder and chairman, Sir Charles Dunstone, which has brought mixed blessings for Carphone. An attempt to import the Best Buy format to the UK, with big out-of-town stores selling everything from kettles to computers, floundered.

Launchedjust as the credit crunch hit consumer confidence, Best Buy UK ended in 2011 with the closure of 11 British stores and the loss of 1,100 jobs.

In the US, however, the partners succeeded in opening 190 standalone mobile phone specialist outlets and franchises in 1,000 stores, and Best Buy paid £840m to take full control of the outlets on its home turf last year.

The performance was less stellar in Europe, where Carphone operates under its own name in the UK and Ireland and under the Phone House brand on the continent.

Underlying earnings have risen from £101m to £137m, but the company has 100 fewer stores today than at the beginning of the joint venture. The recession has held back growth, and Carphone is now conducting an "orderly exit" from France, where it has 245 wholly owned stores and 72 franchises.

Dunstone, who still owns 28% of his company, cheered shareholders by netting a second major profit from Best Buy when their European partnership ended last month. He bought back Best Buy's half-share in Carphone's European shops for £471m, having sold the holding five years earlier for £1.1bn.

During that time, Carphone has also demerged its broadband and TV business, TalkTalk, spinning it off as a separately listed company whose share price has risen sharply over the period. Carphone's executives collected their rewards for the deals last year, with outgoing chief executive Roger Taylor emerging as one of the City's best-paid bosses. He received an estimated £34m in cash and shares, profiting from schemes at both Carphone and TalkTalk.

The share options handed out to senior managers this year cannot be sold until 2015. A total of 16.3m shares, worth over £40m at the current £2.49 share price, have been set aside for the scheme. However, it is likely only 9m shares will be disbursed, meaning managers will share a £22.4m payout.

A spokesman for Carphone said managers were being rewarded for creating a total of £3bn in shareholder value through the Best Buy deals and the increase in share prices at Carphone and TalkTalk.

The scheme does not include staff employed by Virgin Mobile France, a joint venture between Carphone and Virgin Group, who have separate incentives.

Salaries for Carphone's top team were frozen last year, and have not risen since the demerger in March 2010. However, having waved his bonus last year, Taylor did collect the payment in the year to 31 March 2013. As a result, his total pay including pension and benefits rose from £474,000 to £958,000.

A new, long-term incentive scheme is currently being devised, and Taylor's successor ,Andrew Harrison, who currently runs the European retail business, will be one of the participants.

webTitle: Tim Steiner has no reason to sound so indignant

fields.bodyText: Tim Steiner, co-founder and chief executive of Ocado, has many reasons to be cheerful. He has opened the company's second big distribution centre on time and on budget. webTitle: Banks go on offensive over capital levels

fields.bodyText: For 15 years banks, in most instances, chose their capital levels; now an agency of the state decides. So said Paul Tucker, deputy governor of the Bank of England, yesterday in a timely reminder of how regulation is meant to work. It was timely because Barclays and Nationwide have been moaning non-stop since the Bank's Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) last month highlighted the pressing need to get leverage ratios up to 3%. Barclays, at 2.5%, and Nationwide, 2%, feel they have been caught on the hop. Why is this demand suddenly so urgent? In the case of Barclays, the chief executive, Antony Jenkins, has to cut lending if he is made to meet the 3% goal soon, rather than in 2015, as he intended. Sympathy for the grumblers extends only this far: the PRA could have done a better job on the communications front. It should have signalled more clearly that the UK was never going to be satisfied with the international deadline of 2018 to comply with a 3% ratio. It should have outlined its preferred timetable earlier. But the banks cannot pretend they have been whacked with an arbitrary diktat. Come on, a 3% leverage ratio – which allows a bank to have just £3 of equity supporting £100 of lending – is hardly a case of overkill by financial health and safety fanatics. The Independent Banking Commission, and many other observers, thought a 4% ratio ought to be the minimum. Barclays, if it had thought more carefully about capital and leverage, could have made deeper cuts to its bonus pool in recent years, rather than embarking on a "journey" of pay reforms that looks more like a crawl. On the timing front, the PRA has at least made clear when it expects 3% to be achieved – there is "a presumption that we do want this to happen as soon as possible", said the executive director, Andrew Bailey. The vague wording leaves some room for negotiation, but the message to Jenkins seems clear: don't argue with the referee. Sound advice.

webTitle: Ocado boss: 'more high street shops should shut'

fields.bodyText: Tim Steiner, the boss of online grocer Ocado, has launched an attack on high street retailers who are asking the government to review business rates, saying more traditional shops needed to close and telling rivals to stop complaining. Steiner, who recently announced a deal with Morrisons to launch the supermarket's online service, said: "Bricks and mortar retailers need to shut more shops and stop moaning about it." He added that online-only retailers should not be forced to share the burden of business rates, which currently only apply to shops on the high street. He said: "Some bricks and mortar retailers have started to blame business rates for the problems on the high street, which is wrong. They are jumping on the back of the Amazon tax debate. "It is nothing to do with online retail that is causing the problems in the UK and we shouldn't burden online retailers." By contrast, Alliance Boots retail chief executive Alex Gourlay told MPs on Tuesday that a refusal to cut business rates could lead to a further rise in youth unemployment. Gourlay, who is in charge of the UK high street retailer Boots, told the business select committee: "The fundamental facts are ... the indirect taxation levied on retailers in the last ten years is now causing significant structural problems on the high street. "I think there is potentially a risk to the 40% of people that join retail as their first job, which is as the shift towards integrated retail happens, and as there is less physical retailing and more online and supply chain retailing, less people are employed in the sector, and that's a risk. "The next phase could be reduction of space in retail as a whole and a reduction of actual jobs on the shop floor. I think that's a risk given the level of employment that is given to young people by retail and what they get from it." The retail sector is the biggest private-sector employer for young people. However, a series of administrations in the last year, including Blockbuster, HMV, Jessops and Comet, has meant tens of thousands young workers lost their jobs. Last week Terry Duddy, the chief executive of Home Retail Group, owner of Argos and Homebase, warned it was not online competition that caused Jessops to go bust. He blamed business rates, which he called "ludicrous". Sainsbury's chief executive, Justin King, has suggested there should be a local online sales tax similar to that being introduced in the US – a position supported on Tuesday by Tim Fallowfield, the grocer's company secretary, as he appeared before MPs. Fallowfield said: "In the United States they have issued a main-street fairness tax which is redistributing the tax burden by applying a local sales tax, which would apply equally to bricks and mortar retail as well as online retail." Last month King said online retailers have an unfair advantage and that for every £1 his company has saved in corporation tax, it has paid £2.50 in extra business rates. Steiner appeared indifferent to the complaints from the high street retailers and said his company already pays significant tax. He said: "We use vehicles and fuel, and the majority of the diesel we pay for has tax and VAT. We employ over 6,000 people in the UK and make substantial national insurance contributions in the UK and pay business rates on our warehouses. "Trying to tax [online fashion retailers] Asos or Pret-a-Porter for their success would be foolish." The comments come as Ocado revealed a pre-tax loss of £3.8m in the six months to 19 May, compared with a £0.2m profit a year earlier. Steiner said the loss was the result of advisers' fees linked to the Morrisons deal and pre-opening costs of the new distribution centre. Revenue rose nearly 16%% to £356m, while customer numbers increased to 360,000 from 337,000 at the end of the first half last year. Shares closed down 3.2p and 309p, although they are up 316% on a year ago following the tie-up with Morrisons. Business rates are charged on buildings used as business premises and based on a valuation of the property. The fees go to local authorities in the same way as council tax does for domestic properties. The rates are non-negotiable although charity shops are exempt, which has led to landlords being keen to fill empty shops with charity tenants to avoid paying rates on an empty building. Diane Wehrle, marketing and insights director at Springboard, which monitors footfall and vacancy rates on the high street, warned that without flexibility, town centres run the risk of deteriorating. She said: "What you get is a spiral of decline, especially in smaller towns. When a big chain goes bust you get large, empty stores in town centres, but because the overheads are so huge, very few retailers want to take that on. So, customers then leave, making the remaining stores suffer, causing a spiral."

webTitle: Sacked Groupon founder turns to 'motivational' rock music

fields.standfirst: Former boss of online discount website Andrew Mason releases humorous seven-track album Hardly Workin' on iTunes
fields.body:
The founder of Groupon, who was sacked by the discount website earlier this year, has found a new career: fronting a one-man soft rock band.

Andrew Mason, who published a painfully honest resignation letter after he was fired, released the seven-track "motivational business music" album Hardly Workin' on iTunes and Spotify on Monday evening.

Mason, 32, said the album's motivational lyrics "pull some of the most important learnings from my years at the helm of one of the fastest growing businesses in history, and packages them as music".

"Executives, mid-level management and frontline employees are all sure to find valuable takeaways," he said in a blogpost.

He suggested bosses end their next "all-hands meeting" by playing the album's final track It's Up to Us, which includes the lyrics: "Execution. Baby, it's up to us."

Other lyrics include: "I was climbing Machu Picchu, as I beheld the splendid view an idea came for £100m of shareholder value."

On the song The Way to Work, Mason sings: "I look at the road ahead. It reminds me that the journey is the reason I get out of bed and work."

Mason, who left Groupon about $200m richer despite an 80% plunge in the share price under his leadership, advises listeners to follow his path to fortune. "Don't you want a mansion and a yacht like mine?" he croons.

The album has not been terribly well received by reviewers on iTunes. Gpanger said: "Andrew Mason is famous for being a prankster. And I'm pretty sure no self-respecting man would put out this kind of music seriously."

Another review by Rafpm said: "If super generic and unoriginal textbook 'country rock' is your thing… go for it. Lame."

Mason, who may have sought inspiration from his musician wife Jenny Gillespie, left Groupon in April after emailing all 11,000 staff to tell them "I was fired today".

In the frank and funny letter, which referenced Pope Benedict XVI, video game Battletoads and also promised to head off to "fat camp", he said: "I've decided that I'd like to spend more time with my family. Just kidding – I was fired today. If you're wondering why … you haven't been paying attention."

webTitle: Is Ireland right to stick with austerity | Mohamed el-Erian

fields.standfirst: With dire problems after a lending binge, Ireland is in the centre of the eurozone austerity debate, but has it taken the right route?
fields.body:
Both sides of the austerity debate that is now gripping economists and policymakers cite Ireland's experience as evidence for their case. And, however much they try to position the country as a poster-child, neither side is able to convince the other. Yet this tug-of-war is important, because it illustrates the complex range of arguments that are in play. It also demonstrates why more conclusive economic policy making is proving so elusive.

Here is a quick reminder of Ireland's sad recent economic history. Lulled into complacency and excess by ample supplies of artificially cheap financing, Irish banks went on a lending binge. Irresponsible risk-taking and excessive greed outpaced prudential regulation and supervision. The banking system ended up fueling massive speculation, including a huge runup in real-estate prices, only to be brought to its knees when the bubbles popped.

Unlike the many Irish households that lost jobs and part of their wealth, the banks were deemed to be "too big to fail", so Ireland's political elites intervened with state funding. But, by underestimating both the domestic and international aspects of the problem, the authorities transformed a banking problem into a national tragedy.

Rather than restoring the banks to financial health and ensuring responsible behaviour, the Irish economy as a whole was dragged down. Growth collapsed; unemployment spiked. Lacking opportunities, emigration increased – a vivid reminder of how economic crises have wreaked havoc on the country's demographics throughout its history.

Investors withdrew in droves from what was once deemed the "Celtic Tiger". The government had no choice but to request a bailout from the troika – the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, and the European Commission – thereby transferring an important component of national economic governance to an ad hoc, fragile, and sometimes feuding group of institutions.

While other struggling eurozone members also turned to the troika, Ireland stands out in at least two notable ways. First, two democratically elected governments have steadfastly implemented the agreed austerity programmes with little need for waivers and modifications – and thus without the associated political drama. Second, despite enduring considerable pain, Irish society has stuck with the programme, staging few of the street protests that have been common in other austerity-hit countries.

All of this puts Ireland in the middle of three important issues raised in the austerity debates: whether orthodox policy, with its heavy emphasis on immediate budget cuts, can restore conditions for growth, employment gains, and financial stability; whether the benefits of eurozone membership still outweigh the costs for countries that must restructure their economies; and how a small, open economy should strategically position itself in today's world.

Austerity's supporters point to the fact that Ireland is on the verge of "graduating" from the troika's programme. Growth has resumed, financial-risk premia have fallen sharply, foreign investment is picking up, and exports are booming. All of this, they argue, provides the basis for sustainable growth and declining unemployment. Ireland, they conclude, was right to stay in the eurozone, especially because small, open economies that are unanchored can be easily buffeted by a fluid global economy.

"Not so fast," says the other side. The critics of austerity point to the fact that Irish GDP has still not returned to its 2007 level. Unemployment remains far too high, with alarming levels of long-term and youth joblessness. Public debt remains too high as well, and, making matters worse, much more of it is now owed to official rather than private creditors (which would complicate debt restructuring should it become necessary).

The critics reject the argument that small, open economies are necessarily better off in a monetary union, pointing to how well Switzerland is coping. And they lament that eurozone membership means that Ireland's "internal devaluations," which involve significant cuts in real wages, have not yet run their course.

The data on the "Irish experiment" – including the lack of solid counterfactuals – are not conclusive enough for one side to declare a decisive victory. Yet there is some good analytical news. Ireland provides insights that are helpful in understanding how sociopolitical systems, including economically devastated countries such as Cyprus and Greece, have coped so far with shocks that were essentially unthinkable just a few years ago.

On my current visit, most of the Irish citizens with whom I have spoken say that the country had no alternative but to follow the path of austerity. While they appreciate the urgent need for growth and jobs, they believe that this can be achieved only after Ireland's finances are put back on a sound footing. They also argue that, given the banks' irresponsibility, there is no quick way to promote sustained expansion. They are still angry at bankers, but have yet to gain proper retribution.

Ireland's accumulation of wealth during its Celtic Tiger period, when the country surged toward the top of Europe's economic league table, has also been an effective shock absorber. This, together with fears about being left out in the geopolitical cold (despite the country's historical links with Britain and America), dampens Irish enthusiasm for economic experiments outside the eurozone.

Indeed, Irish society seems remarkably hesitant to change course. Right or wrong, Ireland will stick with austerity. Efforts to regain national control of the country's destiny, the Irish seem to believe, must take time. In some of Europe's other struggling countries, however, citizens may well prove less patient.

EasyJet declined 16p to £13.31 after founder Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, said he would vote his 37% stake against the budget airline's plan to buy 135 new aircraft at an investor meeting later this month.

Persimmon fell 16p to £12.24 despite its house sales being boosted by the government's Help to Buy scheme, as it flagged up the slower summer housebuying season ahead. Analyst Anthony Codling at Jefferies said:

The update.. to our mind, sounded a note of caution; we felt the message was 'don't extrapolate current trends'. The expectations being laid were for steady rather than stellar growth.

This perceived caution has also hit rival builders, with Barratt Developments down 8p at 319.1p and Taylor Wimpey 1.8p lower at 98.4p.

But Arm added 2p to 807.5p as the chip designer unveiled a licensing agreement with Japan's Fujitsu Semiconductor involving the UK company's big.LITTLE technology and Mali graphics processing.

Among the mid-caps St Modwen Properties, up 11p at 286p, and home shopping specialist N Brown, 5.1p better at 471.1p, benefited from positive trading updates.

But online grocer Ocado - which has been on a strong run recently - dropped 3.2p to 309p after a bigger than expected half year pre-tax loss. The company also said it was unaware of any takeover approaches.

Finally Thorntons added 5p to 100p after the chocolate specialist said full year results to the end of June would be above market expectations, thanks to sales growth and the results of two years of cost cutting. The company shut down 36 high street shops in 2012 and another 12 in the first half of 2013, as it focussed on boosting online sales and distributing its products through supermarkets. Analyst Bethany Hocking at Investec said:

Thorntons has today published a short announcement reporting that 203 profit will be ahead of expectations (consensus £4.6m, Investec £4.5m) due to a good fourth quarter performance. The company is in the process of working through the detail of recent trading, and will give a fuller update on 15 July. Ahead of this we place our forecasts and target price under review and expect to move both upwards. This is the second time in three months that the company has made such a statement, clearly good news, and we strongly reiterate buy.

webTitle: Eurozone crisis as it happened: Portugal's foreign minister quits as Greece warned over bailout loans

fields.bodyText: More on Portugal: And on that note, we'll close up for the evening. Back tomorrow for the fallout from the latest Portuguese news and all the other developments in the global economy. Thanks for all your comments, and see you soon. Just a quick round-up of the markets, which have generally edged lower again after Monday's gains: • The FTSE 100 finished down 3.84 points at 6303.94 • Germany's Dax dropped 0.92% to 7910 • France's Cac closed 0.66% lower at 3742 • Italy's FTSE MIB ended down 0.61% at 15,365 • Spain's Ibex fell 0.26% to 7886 • In Athens the market lost 3.24% to 823 Meanwhile Wall Street is bucking the trend with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 32 points or 0.22%. It's a crisis in Porgual all right, says Nicholas Spiro, managing director of Spiro Sovereign Strategy: The resignation of two senior ministers in Portugal's ruling coalition in the space of 24 hours turns a major political setback into a full-blown government crisis. This is the clearest indication yet that the rapidly souring politics of economic reform in Portugal are undermining the credibility of the country's bail-out programme. Politically speaking, Portugal's adjustment programme is collapsing. While the market reaction to former finance minister Gaspar's resignation yesterday was fairly muted, the exit of Mr Portas, the head of the junior coalition party, is taking its toll on Portugal's bond market. Make no mistake about it, this is the gravest setback to Portugal's two-year-old bail-out programme - and there have been quite a few of them over the past several months, including legal ones. The back-to-back resignations throw the political opposition to reform in Portugal into sharp relief and pose serious questions about the country's ability to push ahead, let alone exit, its troubled bail-out programme. The full statement from Paulo Portas on his resignation as Portugal's foreign minister can be found here (in Portuguese). A flavour in (sort of) translation: There are known political differences I had with the Minister of Finance. His personal decision to leave allowed the opportunity for a different economic and political cycle. A choice made by the Prime Minister would therefore be especially careful and consensual" The Prime Minister intended to follow the path of mere continuity in the Ministry of Finance. I respected it but disagreed. The Portuguese president's office has confirmed the resignation of foreign minister Paulo Portas, potentially plunging the country into crisis as it struggles to meet the terms of its €78bn bailout and prompting talk of a possible early election. The resignation comes just a day after finance minister Vitor Gaspar quit, but looks more serious. Portas is the leader of the junior party in the country's centre-right coalition government - without the support of his CDS-PP party, the government would lose its majority in parliament. Portas has often been at odds with prime minister Pedro Passos Coelho and Gaspar over the austerity programme brought in as part of the bailout agreement. Ironically, according to local reports, Gaspar's resignation was the trigger for the departure of Portas, since the CDS-PP leader disagreed with the appointment of Maria Luis Albuquerque as the replacement finance minister. Still with Portugal, there are now (unconfirmed) reports the country's foreign minister has resigned. This follows the departure of finance minister Vitor Gaspar yesterday. Portugal's change of finance minister following the resignation of Vitor Gaspar continues to put the country's bonds under pressure. The country's 10 year bond yields have added 12 basis points to 6.52% following the news, but unusually the contamination to the other struggling eurozone economies has been limited. Spain's bond yield is down 3 basis points while Italy is 6 basis points lower. Good for them, not so much for Portugal. It would hardly surprising if the euro was out of favour internationally because of the eurozone crisis (the clue is in the name) but now it's official. The euro slipped last year in terms of reserves held by central banks, according to the European Central Bank, while the US dollar continued to hold its positon as the world's leading currency. The ECB said the euro's share among the currency reserves held globally by central banks fell to 23.9% in 2012 from 25.1% the year before. AP reports: The ECB said the financial crisis that has afflicted the 17-country eurozone was a factor discouraging use of the euro for reserves (no kidding), which are often held in the form of government bonds. Lending across borders in the eurozone has dropped, diminishing the liquidity that reserve holders like to see. Lower liquidity means there are fewer buyers and sellers readily found. In its annual report on international use of the euro, the ECB also found that there was less borrowing in euros internationally by companies because they could get lower interest rates by selling bonds denominated in US. dollars. A key finding of the report was that non-traditional reserve currencies such as the Canadian dollar and the Australian dollar are in greater demand because of their growing economies and better public finances. Another slice of economic news.... US factory orders rose by 2.1% in May, month-on-month. That's a little higher with forecasts. April's data has also been revised up to +1.3%, from +1.0%. All broadly in line with the theory that America's economy is recovering, and there's little market reaction. And on that note, I'm handing over to my colleague Nick Fletcher. The financial markets are pretty quiet, with some traders sitting tight ahead of US unemployment data due on Friday, and the The US and UK stock markets are flattish, while European indices are down, led by the DAX (hit by Fresenius Medical AG, down 8% after warning that the US government is cutting Medicare funding for its kidney dialysis centre). The euro has dropped below the $1.30 mark, while the yen has weakened below ¥100, as the US dollar rallies. With Wall Street open, here's the latest prices: • FTSE 100: flat at 6307 • Dow Jones; up 40 points at 15014, 15021, +0.3% • German DAX: down 79 points at 7095,-1% • French CAC: down 22 points at 3745, -0.6% • Spanish IBEX: down 2 points at 7904, - 0.04% • Italian FTSE MIB: down 86 points at 15371, -0.57% * - Having said that, the Indian central bank is rumoured to be urging traders to stop speculating on the rupee, which is close to its record low levels: Unfortunate mea culpa from Eurostat today. Europe's statistics body has admitted that the eurozone jobless rate is in fact a record high of 12.2%, not 12.1% as reported yesterday. The reason? "An error in the loading of the French data". Sacre Bleu! Here's the updated release. A group of Greek state school teachers have held a protest outside the ministery of administrative reform in Athens today. The demonstration coincided with the latest meetings between Troika officials and Greek ministers, and was designed to show public anger over the country's financial programme. In particular, the job losses and spending cuts being demanded by the Troika. Riot police were out in force as teachers chanted slogans and waved banners, but the protests appear to be peaceful (no one had to stay behind after class, anyway...) Greece's health minister Adonis Georgiadis has told local reporters in Athens following his meeting with the troika that the two sides reached “total agreement.” It's not clear what they've agreed to, though, as EKathimerini reports: “[The ministry] raised the issue that there can be no further cuts in health spending,” Georgiadis said adding however that more reforms were on the way. Back to Greece, and the deputy chief executive at its bank rescue fund has reportedly resigned. Reuters says that deputy CEO Marios Koliopoulos quit the Hellenic Financial Stability Fund, in a row over legal procedures. HFSF's role is to recapitalize Greece's major banks, and help wind down the ones that aren't seen as viable. Full story here. Elsewhere in parliament, economist Vicky Pryce called for decisive action, including a bond-buying programme from the European Central Bank, when she appeared at a House of Lords committee today. It was an early public appearance from Pryce since she was released from prison following her conviction after taking speeding points for her ex-husband, the former cabinet minister Chris Huhne. As she entered the meeting, Pryce told waiting reporters that she was "feeling just fine", before being ushered into room 3 on the Palace of Westminster's select committee corridor. The electronic tag she is still obliged to wear after being released from prison two months into an eight-month sentence was not visible beneath her outfit. There was no mention of her prison experiences at the hearing of the cross-party subcommittee on economic and financial affairs – where Pryce said she could not see an immediate end to the crisis afflicting the single currency. Structural reforms would take far too long, she said, advocating "decisive action" to tackle debt levels and a stimulus package including the European Central Bank being allowed to buy bonds. More here: Vicky Pryce returns to public eye with House of Lords committee appearance David Cameron's statement on the EU council meeting, and the subsequent questions and answers, are being streamed live now here. So far, Cameron has attacked the "unacceptable and frustrating" attempt to unpick Britain's rebate, which would have cost Britain £1.5bn but was rejected. Labour leader Ed Miliband had some fun teasing the PM over his "flowery" comments that in Brussels you need to be ready for an ambush, so it's essential to "lock and load and have one up the spout" Miliband joked: It sounds more "Carry On Up The Council" than "High Noon". Cameron, though, responds that every other country at the European Council wants to get rid of Britain's rebate (and other top eurocrats too), and he's determined to defend it. (do follow Andrew Sparrow's rolling blog for full coverage) David Cameron is giving a statement to the UK parliament now on last week's EU Summit -- where he apparently rejected an attack on the British rebate. He's also discussing the situation in Afghanistan. My colleague Andrew Sparrow is liveblogging the whole statement here. I'll keep an ear pointed at Westminster for any eurozone-related points... Encouraging economic news in the UK this morning, with the construction sector posting its fastest growth in over a year in June. Here's the details: UK construction sector grows for second consecutive month The UK's construction sector grew for a second month in June, boosted by a rise in house building and supporting expectations that economic growth accelerated in the second quarter. Growth in both output and new orders pushed the Markit/CIPS construction purchasing managers' index (PMI) to 51 from 50.8 in May, where anything above 50 indicates expansion. It was the highest level since May 2012. Heads-up. Hannes Swoboda, head of the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, is will be holding a Facebook chat in an hour's time (2pm CET/1pm BST) with David Gow, our former European business editor, on the eurozone crisis. it's on the back of their new book – Basta! An End to Austerity – on the mistakes made since the crisis began, and how politicians should change course, The European Commission is denying that Greece has been set a firm, three-day deadline to reach an agreement with the troika over its bailout plan. An EC spokesperson tried to calm the situation, saying that reports of Athens being given until Friday to satisfy its lenders is "something from nothing". This follows Reuters' report that four eurozone officials believe time is running out for Athens (see 8.57am for the story) Nikos Chrysoloras, Kathimerini's man in Brussels, adds: The EC added that eurozone finance ministers will consider whether to pay Greece's next aid tranche – whether all in one part, or in stages – on Monday. So, even if there isn't anything as gripping as a three-day deadline, pressure is building to make progress by the start of next week. And as Peter Spiegel of the FT flags up, there's a risk that the International Monetary Fund could walk away from Greece if the funding shortfalls in its financial programme aren't fixed by the end of July (full stort here) Portuguese government debt has fallen in value this morning as investors digest the resignation of finance minister Vitor Gaspar. Gaspar, who played a key role in drawing up and implementing Portugal's unpopular austerity programme, quit last night - blaming shrinking public support for the plan. Analysts say Gaspar's resignation is a blow to the Lisbon government. Nicholas Spiro, managing director at Spiro Sovereign Strategy in London, warned: Portugal's economic overhaul has suffered a number of setbacks of late, and Mr. Gaspar's unexpected exit hardly inspires confidence. Gaspar's resignation letter to Portuguese PM Pedro Passos-Coelho (online here, in Portuguese). showed that he had been considering his position for months, and may have lost faith in his own austerity programme (he writes that his departure should strenthen the prime minister's "leadership and the cohesion of the cabinet"). Open Europe points out that Portugal still faces significant challenges in exiting its bailout. It writes: Domestic demand, government spending and investment are contracting sharply, leaving the country heavily reliant on uncertain export growth to drive the economy. By cutting wages and costs at home (internal devaluation), Portugal has in recent years improved its level of competitiveness in the eurozone relative to Germany. However, this trend actually started to reverse sharply in 2012, meaning that the divergence between countries such as Portugal and Germany has begun growing again – exactly the sort of imbalance the eurozone is seeking to close. In its austerity efforts, Portugal is now coming up against serious political and constitutional limits. For the second time, the country’s constitutional court has ruled against public sector wage cuts – a key plank in the country’s EU-mandated austerity plan – while the previous political consensus in the parliament for austerity has evaporated. Gaspar's successor, Maria Luis Albuquerque, will be inaugurated at 5pm today. As Treasury secretary, she's handled Portugal's privatisation programme. And in the bond markets, Portuguese 10-year bonds are now trading at a yield of 6.49%. That's 10 basis points, or 0.1% higher, than last night, and closer to the 7% mark that's generally seen as unsustainable. Spanish and Italian debt has strengthened a little this morning (with 10-year yields of 4.5% and 4.4%). From Cyprus, crisis-watcher Yiannis Mouzakis flags up that Greece wouldn't be facing a budget shortfall if central banks had agreed to share the pain and rolled over their holdings of Geek debts last year. And here's more early reaction to the news that the clock is once again ticking for Greece (see 8.57am). With pressure building on Greece to satisfy the Troika's demands by the end of the week, top officials have now arrived at the Greek labour ministry. They'll be meeting with labour minister Yiannis Vroutsis today, who (as mantioned ealier) had already said that Greece's minimum wage can't be cut again. And here's Reuters full story on Greece, and the warning from EU officials that time is short.... Greece has three days to reassure its lenders it can deliver on conditions attached to its international bailout in order to receive the next tranche of aid, four euro zone officials said on Tuesday. Athens and its creditors unlocking €8.1bn of rescue loans resumed talks on Monday on after a two-week break during which the government almost collapsed over redundancies at state broadcaster ERT. There is a general dissatisfaction with progress in Greece when it comes to reforming its public sector, such as tax and custom collection or health care services, a senior euro zone official involved in negotiations said. "All agreed that Greece has to deliver before the Eurogroup on Monday. That's why they must present again on Friday," a second source told Reuters. This adds fuel to the theory that the €8bn tranche could be split into a few parts, and only handed over when Athens hits certain targets. No wonder government officials have been telling us that negotiations will be "very tough". EU officials are reiterating the point that Greece needs to satisfy the Troika in time for next Monday's meeting of the eurogroup (eurozone finance ministers) Via the Reuters terminal: • GREECE HAS THREE DAYS TO REASSURE LENDERS IT CAN DELIVER ON BAILOUT PLEDGES IN ORDER TO RECEIVE NEXT AID TRANCHE - EU OFFICIALS • EURO ZONE FINANCE MINISTERS TO DEBATE GREECE AND DECIDE ON FURTHER ACTION ON JULY 8 - EU OFFICIALS In the financial world, Australia's central bank proved that you can talk down your currency without actually easing monetary policy. The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates at their current record low of 2.75% overnight, as expected. But the Australian dollar dropped half a cent against its US dollar, not far from a three-year-low, after the RBA hinted at future cuts. Governor Glenn Stevens said the RBA: .. decided that the stance of monetary policy remained appropriate for the time being. The Board also judged that the inflation outlook, as currently assessed, may provide some scope for further easing, should that be required to support demand. Another sign that central bankers believe we're some way from the end of the financial crisis that began over five years ago. With a general election looming, the Wall Street Journal argues that that RBA might not fancy sparking a political row with a rate cut today, explaining: In 2007, the center-right John Howard government was angered by the perceived advantage a rate hike gave to Mr Rudd's Labor Party during the election campaign. The Greek government hoped to reach a deal with the Troika in time for next Monday's meeting of eurogroup ministers, so they could approve its €8bn loan. But as Greece's Kathimerini newspaper flags up, there is pessimism in Athens that the deadline will be hit: It writes: Government officials on Monday resumed tough negotiations with troika envoys on a range of economic reforms that Athens must implement in order to secure further rescue loans, including a delayed overhaul of the civil service, with sources indicating that there was hope for some concessions although it appeared unlikely that talks would be completed in time for next Monday’s Eurogroup summit. Another issue on the table is Greece's emergency property tax. The Athens government hopes it could be paid in five installments (which would ease the pressure on households), while the Troika wants it paid in four (meaning more revenue this year). Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest developments across the eurozone, the financial markets and the world economy. Eurozone tensions are building again as the Greek government resumes talks with its international lenders today over its austerity programme. At stake, the next tranche of aid loans for Greece, worth over €8bn. Oficials from the Troika are due to meet with the country's new health minister, Adonis Georgidis, to discuss a €1bn funding gap in Greece's finances caused by debts at its main healthcare provider, EOPYY. There is concern in Greece that the Troika will demand further cutbacks to keep Greece 'on track' with its bailout targets. Georgidis has already hinted at closing some state hospitals to fix the black hole.... Troika officials are also scheduled to hold talks with labour minister Yiannis Vroutsis today, who has already refused to accept any further cuts to the minimum wage. The Troika have already been pressuring Athens to push on with its promised overhaul of the civil service -- laying off 15,000 people by the end of 2015. As our Athens correspondent Helena Smith reported last night, government insiders fear that the €8bn aid tranche will only be doled out in installments: The troika has made clear that it will only disburse aid when, and if, specific reforms are taken. The likelihood of the country’s super tranche – €8.1bn in aid – being dispatched in installments is now a given. “It’s going to make for a very heavy climate but they have made it very clear that that is what they are going to do,” said one insider. “Every time we announce a measure, we’ll get an installment. That is the premise they are working on.” Difficult times. And the situation doesn't look much better in Portugal, where finance minister Vitor Gaspar resigned last night. His successor, treasury secretary, Maria Luís Albuquerque, will be sworn in this afternoon. I'll be watching events through in Athens and beyond through the day.....

There are known political differences I had with the Minister of Finance. His personal decision to leave allowed the opportunity for a different economic and political cycle. A choice made by the Prime Minister would therefore be especially careful and consensual"

The Prime Minister intended to follow the path of mere continuity in the Ministry of Finance. I respected it but disagreed.

5.24pm BST

Portugal faces new crisis as foreign minister and coalition partner quits

The Portuguese president's office has confirmed the resignation of foreign minister Paulo Portas, potentially plunging the country into crisis as it struggles to meet the terms of its €78bn bailout and prompting talk of a possible early election.

The resignation comes just a day after finance minister Vitor Gaspar quit, but looks more serious. Portas is the leader of the junior party in the country's centre-right coalition government - without the support of his CDS-PP party, the government would lose its majority in parliament.

Portas has often been at odds with prime minister Pedro Passos Coelho and Gaspar over the austerity programme brought in as part of the bailout agreement.

Ironically, according to local reports, Gaspar's resignation was the trigger for the departure of Portas, since the CDS-PP leader disagreed with the appointment of Maria Luis Albuquerque as the replacement finance minister.

4.44pm BST

Portugal's foreign minister reportedly resigns

Still with Portugal, there are now (unconfirmed) reports the country's foreign minister has resigned. This follows the departure of finance minister Vitor Gaspar yesterday.

Updated at 4.44pm BST

4.28pm BST

Portugal bond yields continue to move higher

Portugal's change of finance minister following the resignation of Vitor Gaspar continues to put the country's bonds under pressure.

The country's 10 year bond yields have added 12 basis points to 6.52% following the news, but unusually the contamination to the other struggling eurozone economies has been limited. Spain's bond yield is down 3 basis points while Italy is 6 basis points lower. Good for them, not so much for Portugal.

3.57pm BST

Euro out of favour with central banks

It would hardly surprising if the euro was out of favour internationally because of the eurozone crisis (the clue is in the name) but now it's official.

The euro slipped last year in terms of reserves held by central banks, according to the European Central Bank, while the US dollar continued to hold its positon as the world's leading currency.

The ECB said the euro's share among the currency reserves held globally by central banks fell to 23.9% in 2012 from 25.1% the year before. AP reports:

The ECB said the financial crisis that has afflicted the 17-country eurozone was a factor discouraging use of the euro for reserves (no kidding), which are often held in the form of government bonds. Lending across borders in the eurozone has dropped, diminishing the liquidity that reserve holders like to see. Lower liquidity means there are fewer buyers and sellers readily found.

In its annual report on international use of the euro, the ECB also found that there was less borrowing in euros internationally by companies because they could get lower interest rates by selling bonds denominated in US. dollars.

A key finding of the report was that non-traditional reserve currencies such as the Canadian dollar and the Australian dollar are in greater demand because of their growing economies and better public finances.

Updated at 3.59pm BST

US factory orders

Another slice of economic news.... US factory orders rose by 2.1% in May, month-on-month. That's a little higher with forecasts. April's data has also been revised up to +1.3%, from +1.0%.

All broadly in line with the theory that America's economy is recovering, and there's little market reaction.

In the City

The financial markets are pretty quiet, with some traders sitting tight ahead of US unemployment data due on Friday, and the

The reason? "An error in the loading of the French data". Sacre Bleu!

Updated at 2.28pm BST

1.51pm BST

Photos: Teachers hold anti-austerity protest in Athens

A group of Greek state school teachers have held a protest outside the ministery of administrative reform in Athens today.

The demonstration coincided with the latest meetings between Troika officials and Greek ministers, and was designed to show public anger over the country's financial programme. In particular, the job losses and spending cuts being demanded by the Troika.

Riot police were out in force as teachers chanted slogans and waved banners, but the protests appear to be peaceful (no one had to stay behind after class, anyway...)

1.36pm BST

Greece's health minister Adonis Georgiadis has told local reporters in Athens following his meeting with the troika that the two sides reached “total agreement.”

It's not clear what they've agreed to, though, as EKathimerini reports:

“[The ministry] raised the issue that there can be no further cuts in health spending,” Georgiadis said adding however that more reforms were on the way.

1.10pm BST

Back to Greece, and the deputy chief executive at its bank rescue fund has reportedly resigned.

Reuters says that deputy CEO Marios Koliopoulos quit the Hellenic Financial Stability Fund, in a row over legal procedures. HFSF's role is to recapitalize Greece's major banks, and help wind down the ones that aren't seen as viable.

Full story here.

Elsewhere in parliament, economist Vicky Pryce called for decisive action, including a bond-buying programme from the European Central Bank, when she appeared at a House of Lords committee today.

It was an early public appearance from Pryce since she was released from prison following her conviction after taking speeding points for her ex-husband, the former cabinet minister Chris Huhne.

As she entered the meeting, Pryce told waiting reporters that she was "feeling just fine", before being ushered into room 3 on the Palace of Westminster's select committee corridor.

The electronic tag she is still obliged to wear after being released from prison two months into an eight-month sentence was not visible beneath her outfit.

There was no mention of her prison experiences at the hearing of the cross-party subcommittee on economic and financial affairs – where Pryce said she could not see an immediate end to the crisis afflicting the single currency.

Structural reforms would take far too long, she said, advocating "decisive action" to tackle debt levels and a stimulus package including the European Central Bank being allowed to buy bonds.

Key event

So far, Cameron has attacked the "unacceptable and frustrating" attempt to unpick Britain's rebate, which would have cost Britain £1.5bn but was rejected.

Labour leader Ed Miliband had some fun teasing the PM over his "flowery" comments that in Brussels you need to be ready for an ambush, so it's essential to "lock and load and have one up the spout"

Miliband joked:

My colleague Andrew Sparrow is liveblogging the whole statement here. I'll keep an ear pointed at Westminster for any eurozone-related points...

Here's the details: UK construction sector grows for second consecutive month

The UK's construction sector grew for a second month in June, boosted by a rise in house building and supporting expectations that economic growth accelerated in the second quarter.

Growth in both output and new orders pushed the Markit/CIPS construction purchasing managers' index (PMI) to 51 from 50.8 in May, where anything above 50 indicates expansion. It was the highest level since May 2012.

Heads-up. Hannes Swoboda, head of the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, is will be holding a Facebook chat in an hour's time (2pm CET/1pm BST) with David Gow, our former European business editor, on the eurozone crisis.

The European Commission is denying that Greece has been set a firm, three-day deadline to reach an agreement with the troika over its bailout plan.

An EC spokesperson tried to calm the situation, saying that reports of Athens being given until Friday to satisfy its lenders is "something from nothing".

This follows Reuters' report that four eurozone officials believe time is running out for Athens (see 8.57am for the story)

The EC added that eurozone finance ministers will consider whether to pay Greece's next aid tranche – whether all in one part, or in stages – on Monday.

So, even if there isn't anything as gripping as a three-day deadline, pressure is building to make progress by the start of next week.

11.09am BST

Portuguese government debt has fallen in value this morning as investors digest the resignation of finance minister Vitor Gaspar.

Gaspar, who played a key role in drawing up and implementing Portugal's unpopular austerity programme, quit last night - blaming shrinking public support for the plan.

Analysts say Gaspar's resignation is a blow to the Lisbon government. Nicholas Spiro, managing director at Spiro Sovereign Strategy in London, warned:

Portugal's economic overhaul has suffered a number of setbacks of late, and Mr. Gaspar's unexpected exit hardly inspires confidence.

Gaspar's resignation letter to Portuguese PM Pedro Passos-Coelho (online here, in Portuguese). showed that he had been considering his position for months, and may have lost faith in his own austerity programme (he writes that his departure should strenthen the prime minister's "leadership and the cohesion of the cabinet").

Open Europe points out that Portugal still faces significant challenges in exiting its bailout. It writes:

  • Domestic demand, government spending and investment are contracting sharply, leaving the country heavily reliant on uncertain export growth to drive the economy. 
  • By cutting wages and costs at home (internal devaluation), Portugal has in recent years improved its level of competitiveness in the eurozone relative to Germany. However, this trend actually started to reverse sharply in 2012, meaning that the divergence between countries such as Portugal and Germany has begun growing again – exactly the sort of imbalance the eurozone is seeking to close. 
  • In its austerity efforts, Portugal is now coming up against serious political and constitutional limits. Gaspar's successor, Maria Luis Albuquerque, will be inaugurated at 5pm today. As Treasury secretary, she's handled Portugal's privatisation programme.

And in the bond markets, Portuguese 10-year bonds are now trading at a yield of 6.49%. That's 10 basis points, or 0.1% higher, than last night, and closer to the 7% mark that's generally seen as unsustainable.

Spanish and Italian debt has strengthened a little this morning (with 10-year yields of 4.5% and 4.4%).

10.14am BST

Early reaction

From Cyprus, crisis-watcher Yiannis Mouzakis flags up that Greece wouldn't be facing a budget shortfall if central banks had agreed to share the pain and rolled over their holdings of Geek debts last year.

And here's more early reaction to the news that the clock is once again ticking for Greece (see 8.57am).

9.47am BST

Photos: Troika officials arrive for latest talks

With pressure building on Greece to satisfy the Troika's demands by the end of the week, top officials have now arrived at the Greek labour ministry.

They'll be meeting with labour minister Yiannis Vroutsis today, who (as mantioned ealier) had already said that Greece's minimum wage can't be cut again.

Updated at 10.20am BST

8.57am BST

Reuters: Greece must deliver

And here's Reuters full story on Greece, and the warning from EU officials that time is short....

Greece has three days to reassure its lenders it can deliver on conditions attached to its international bailout in order to receive the next tranche of aid, four euro zone officials said on Tuesday.

Athens and its creditors unlocking €8.1bn of rescue loans resumed talks on Monday on after a two-week break during which the government almost collapsed over redundancies at state broadcaster ERT. There is a general dissatisfaction with progress in Greece when it comes to reforming its public sector, such as tax and custom collection or health care services, a senior euro zone official involved in negotiations said.

"All agreed that Greece has to deliver before the Eurogroup on Monday. That's why they must present again on Friday," a second source told Reuters.

This adds fuel to the theory that the €8bn tranche could be split into a few parts, and only handed over when Athens hits certain targets.

No wonder government officials have been telling us that negotiations will be "very tough".

8.38am BST

EU officials: Greece has three days...

EU officials are reiterating the point that Greece needs to satisfy the Troika in time for next Monday's meeting of the eurogroup (eurozone finance ministers)

Via the Reuters terminal:

• GREECE HAS THREE DAYS TO REASSURE LENDERS IT CAN DELIVER ON BAILOUT PLEDGES IN ORDER TO RECEIVE NEXT AID TRANCHE - EU OFFICIALS

• EURO ZONE FINANCE MINISTERS TO DEBATE GREECE AND DECIDE ON FURTHER ACTION ON JULY 8 - EU OFFICIALS 

8.26am BST

In the financial world, Australia's central bank proved that you can talk down your currency without actually easing monetary policy.

The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates at their current record low of 2.75% overnight, as expected. But the Australian dollar dropped half a cent against its US dollar, not far from a three-year-low, after the RBA hinted at future cuts.

Governor Glenn Stevens said the RBA:

.. decided that the stance of monetary policy remained appropriate for the time being. The Board also judged that the inflation outlook, as currently assessed, may provide some scope for further easing, should that be required to support demand.

Another sign that central bankers believe we're some way from the end of the financial crisis that began over five years ago.

With a general election looming, the Wall Street Journal argues that that RBA might not fancy sparking a political row with a rate cut today, explaining:

In 2007, the center-right John Howard government was angered by the perceived advantage a rate hike gave to Mr Rudd's Labor Party during the election campaign.

Updated at 8.27am BST

8.17am BST

Clock ticking....

The Greek government hoped to reach a deal with the Troika in time for next Monday's meeting of eurogroup ministers, so they could approve its €8bn loan. But as Greece's Kathimerini newspaper flags up, there is pessimism in Athens that the deadline will be hit:

It writes:

Government officials on Monday resumed tough negotiations with troika envoys on a range of economic reforms that Athens must implement in order to secure further rescue loans, including a delayed overhaul of the civil service, with sources indicating that there was hope for some concessions although it appeared unlikely that talks would be completed in time for next Monday’s Eurogroup summit.

Another issue on the table is Greece's emergency property tax. The Athens government hopes it could be paid in five installments (which would ease the pressure on households), while the Troika wants it paid in four (meaning more revenue this year).

Updated at 8.18am BST

7.57am BST

Greece holds fresh talks with the Troika

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest developments across the eurozone, the financial markets and the world economy.

Eurozone tensions are building again as the Greek government resumes talks with its international lenders today over its austerity programme. At stake, the next tranche of aid loans for Greece, worth over €8bn.

Oficials from the Troika are due to meet with the country's new health minister, Adonis Georgidis, to discuss a €1bn funding gap in Greece's finances caused by debts at its main healthcare provider, EOPYY.

There is concern in Greece that the Troika will demand further cutbacks to keep Greece 'on track' with its bailout targets. Georgidis has already hinted at closing some state hospitals to fix the black hole....

Troika officials are also scheduled to hold talks with labour minister Yiannis Vroutsis today, who has already refused to accept any further cuts to the minimum wage.

The Troika have already been pressuring Athens to push on with its promised overhaul of the civil service -- laying off 15,000 people by the end of 2015.

As our Athens correspondent Helena Smith reported last night, government insiders fear that the €8bn aid tranche will only be doled out in installments:

The troika has made clear that it will only disburse aid when, and if, specific reforms are taken. The likelihood of the country’s super tranche – €8.1bn in aid – being dispatched in installments is now a given.

“It’s going to make for a very heavy climate but they have made it very clear that that is what they are going to do,” said one insider. “Every time we announce a measure, we’ll get an installment. That is the premise they are working on.”

Difficult times. And the situation doesn't look much better in Portugal, where finance minister Vitor Gaspar resigned last night. His successor, treasury secretary, Maria Luís Albuquerque, will be sworn in this afternoon.

I'll be watching events through in Athens and beyond through the day.....
fields.trailText: Athens under pressure to satisfy its lenders and unlock €8bn of aid by Monday, as talks resume with Troika officials

webTitle: John Lewis loses fashion retail guru Peter Ruis to Jigsaw

fields.standfirst: The man who helped the partners step out of their slippers is leaving to become boss of the high-street clothes chain
fields.body:
Peter Ruis, the man who transformed John Lewis from a staid shop best known for its sensible cardigans and cosy slippers into a fashion mecca, is leaving the department store to become the boss of Jigsaw.

After almost nine years at the retailer, six in charge of fashion, Ruis leaves the clothing side of the business in good shape. Fashion sales topped £1.1bn last year, up from £700m in 2005, after a string of rave reviews for its own-label brand and designer collections.

Andy Street, managing director at John Lewis, said everyone would be sad to see Ruis go. "Peter has revolutionised our fashion, home and technology offer," he said.

Ruis, who has also worked at Marks & Spencer, starts at Jigsaw in September, raising hopes that he can sprinkle some magic over the 61-store retailer, which analysts say has become dull and tired.

Jigsaw has lost its status as a prominent niche brand on the UK high street, according to Maureen Hinton, a retail analyst at Verdict. She said: "It seems to have been stuck in a rut and has got an air of yesterday about it … It just needs someone to go in there and shake it up and rejuvenate it."

"[Peter Ruis] has got a very good brand background. He understands what brands need to do to stand out."

Jigsaw had the potential to be a successful niche brand, like Hobbs and Ted Baker, she added, "but at the moment, it is just a bit dull."

Ruis said he was "hugely excited to be joining such an iconic British brand", which he said had "huge untapped potential".

Under Ruis's stewardship, John Lewis clothing become a talking point on the fashion pages. He dropped lines with an old-fashioned reputation, such as the British label Jacques Vert, and introduced a range of well-received new collections, such as Somerset, by Alice Temperley, and the cheaper brand Kin.

The department store sought to burnish its fashion credentials further last month by putting John Lewis's own-brand menswear on the catwalk at an elite London fashion event.

"We have taken the customer with us, and the more fashionable we get, the more interested they become," Ruis told the Observer in an interview in March.

He attributed the retailer's success to attracting well-heeled customers across the age range, rather than targeting the 18- 24-year-olds looking for a party outfit.

"Historically, we have been told that our customers are more affluent and a bit older, but increasingly our research has shown that to be a bit simplistic," he said.

Paula Nickolds will take over his job as buying and brand director in the autumn. Nickolds, 40, joined the company as a graduate trainee 19 years ago and has worked her way up to her current position, as buying director for home products.

"She has a got a good understanding of the John Lewis customer and where [the business] is going as well," Hinton said."
